text: Patient: Oh. Doctor: Now one of the things that I also wanted to discuss with you was some um of the clinical trials that we’re doing. In other words, research studies – Patient: Uh huh. DOC - investigating new approaches which might not be approved for prostate cancer. Doctor: For prostate cancer. And one of the um trials that we’re doing, which we are quite excited about is this concept of using high doses of testosterone as a therapy for prostate cancer. Patient: As a therapy? Now testosterone feeds the cancer, correct? Doctor: Correct. I knew you’d say that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So this is quite a paradoxical approach. Patient: Okay, good. Doctor: And it turns out that you’re absolutely right. We’ve known for a long time for about seventy years that testosterone can feed into your prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: However, we have recently discovered in the last three or four years that they can take a patient who has had low testosterone levels for a very long time they call that hormone-resistant prostate cancer or castration-resistant prostate cancer is another term Patient: Yeah.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
